prior_works.title: A statistical method for evaluating systematic relationships (UPGMA)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Gray et al.’s merge-by-maximum-average-dot-product is the average-linkage paradigm instantiated with a dot-product similarity (Gram) matrix, directly extending the classical UPGMA linkage from distances to inner-product similarities.

prior_works.title: A cost function for hierarchical clustering
prior_works.role: Objective framework linking similarity matrices to tree quality
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By casting hierarchical clustering as optimizing a similarity-based objective, this work motivates using inner-product (dot product) similarities and analyzing the induced tree geometry—precisely the lens used to justify and study the proposed dot-product linkage.

prior_works.title: Maximum-likelihood estimation of evolutionary trees from continuous characters
prior_works.role: Phylogenetic continuous-trait model where covariance equals shared ancestry
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s probabilistic model mirrors Felsenstein’s Brownian-motion-on-a-tree insight that pairwise covariances encode common ancestry; averaging dot products across dimensions exploits this covariance–tree correspondence to recover the hidden hierarchy.

prior_works.title: Learning Latent Tree Graphical Models
prior_works.role: Theory for recovering latent tree structure from pairwise statistics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work establishes that appropriately transformed pairwise correlations or information distances identify latent tree structure, directly underpinning Gray et al.’s use of pairwise dot products to reconstruct the generative hierarchy.

prior_works.title: Treelets: An adaptive multi-scale basis for sparse unordered data
prior_works.role: Inner-product/covariance-based hierarchical construction with high-dimensional benefits
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Treelets demonstrated that hierarchical merging driven by covariances (inner products) can uncover multiscale latent structure and benefits from high dimensionality, informing both the algorithmic choice of dot-product linkage and the d→∞ concentration arguments.

prior_works.title: The neighbor-joining method: a new method for reconstructing phylogenetic trees
prior_works.role: Reconstruction of additive trees from pairwise proximities
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Neighbor-joining showed that additive tree geometry can be recovered from pairwise proximities, a guiding principle for translating Gray et al.’s probabilistic model into a tree estimable from pairwise dot products.

prior_works.title: Rates of convergence for the cluster tree
prior_works.role: Theory of recovering an underlying hierarchical cluster structure from finite samples
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By formalizing when and how hierarchical structure (the cluster tree) can be consistently estimated from data, this work frames the recovery guarantees that Gray et al. establish for dot-product agglomerative trees under their model.

synthesis_narrative: Gray et al. recast agglomerative hierarchical clustering through the lens of inner-product similarity, proposing to merge clusters by maximum average dot product and proving that the resulting dendrogram recovers a latent generative hierarchy. The algorithmic backbone is classic average linkage (UPGMA), now instantiated on a Gram matrix, aligning with Dasgupta’s objective perspective that hierarchical clustering quality can be analyzed via similarity-based costs. Their probabilistic justification draws directly on phylogenetic continuous-trait models (Felsenstein), where Brownian motion on a tree yields covariances equal to shared ancestry; in high dimensions, averaged dot products reliably estimate these covariances, revealing the tree’s geometry. Parallel to results in latent tree graphical models (Choi–Tan–Anandkumar–Willsky), they leverage the principle that pairwise statistics suffice to identify tree structure, but specialize it to dot products of high-dimensional vectors. Methodologically, the choice of inner-product-based merging echoes Treelets, which showed that covariance-driven hierarchical constructions can uncover multiscale latent organization and enjoy concentration benefits as dimension grows. The broader tree-reconstruction paradigm (Neighbor-Joining) reinforces that additive tree metrics are recoverable from pairwise proximities, supporting their translation from model to estimable geometry. Finally, the work situates within a theory of hierarchical recovery from finite samples (Chaudhuri–Dasgupta), extending that ethos to a new graphical model and demonstrating that increasing both sample size and dimension strengthens consistent recovery of the hidden hierarchy.
